scenarios.longText: The program or project requirements change frequently or cannot be clearly defined due to conflicting information received from various stakeholders.
It has become apparent that the program or project is no longer going to deliver what the customer needs.

The combination of the advanced and technical nature of the program or project has several interconnected components and/or processes that have not been encountered previously by the organization. In addition, team members do not have the necessary skills or experience.
The technologies available at the beginning of the program or project will be eclipsed by new technologies required to complete the deliverables.
The program or project team members are dispersed globally, and have cultural, language, and time zone challenges.

The program or project has numerous stakeholders, with disparate teams and sponsors from multiple organizations, each with their own methods and processes. There are also various third-party suppliers and the management structure and responsibilities are unclear.
Requirements originate from a variety of sources with differing or conflicting objectives. In addition, regulatory or quality requirements may have overarching impact to the program or project.

The program or project has encountered an increasing volume of change requests. People are no longer motivated to do their work. In addition, there are unresolved claims from the suppliers, customer, or contractor. Many of the key performance indicators and other metrics are pointing to the trend that the program or project is in trouble.

The project is unlikely to meet the agreed dates due to the numerous dependencies and relationships and lack of supplier or contractor commitment to the dates. This is compounded by the amount of change that the project is encountering.
The degree of complexity encountered in the program or project is impeding efforts at performance assessment and reporting.
The project is funded from various sponsors and sources each with their own objectives and agendas.

The program or project manager is having difficulty applying and acquiring organizational resources for the program or project activities. In addition, the functional group’s objectives are not in alignment with the goals and objectives of the program or project.
